Welcome to Mnemonica

You are a citizen of Mnemonica. You moved here voluntarily. We have documentation. You signed it. You will not remember signing it. This is normal.

If you are reading this for what feels like the first time, it is not. Our records show you have accessed this portal approximately 347 times. Please stop emailing us about "waking up in a strange apartment." It is your apartment. The neon green walls were your choice.

I founded this city after my doctoral thesis, "The Espresso of Forgetting: Caffeine as Mnemonic Anchor in Post-Temporal Civic Architecture," was rejected by 14 universities and one Starbucks. I was right. They were wrong. You're welcome.

Municipal Staff Directory

All Feline Staff

Per Municipal Ordinance ¬ß2 ("The Whiskers Act"), all city government positions are held by cats. This is not negotiable. A human once applied for the position of Comptroller. He was given a ball of yarn and gently redirected.

Clementine Whiskers
City Manager & Founder
Calico. Former barista. Former philosopher. Current city manager. Clementine's doctoral thesis on caffeine-as-memory-anchor was rejected 14 times, which she considers "proof of its genius." Founded Mnemonica in what she describes as "a moment of perfect clarity that I ironically cannot remember." Believes deeply that color is the only thing that survives forgetting. Has a complicated relationship with her mother, who is a barn cat in Wisconsin and does not return calls.
Desk location: 4th floor, corner office. The one with 47 coffee mugs and a framed rejection letter from the University of Helsinki.
Tuna Rodriguez
Captain, Color Enforcement Division
Orange tabby. Nine pounds of pure law. Tuna joined the CED after a personal tragedy: his favorite napping spot was painted beige by a rogue contractor. He woke up on it and "felt nothing." He has not felt nothing since. Known for his signature move of knocking contraband paint off tables during raids. Has never once apologized.
Holds the department record: 23 consecutive beige-related arrests in a single cycle. Most suspects didn't remember the arrest. Neither did Tuna. The paperwork persists.
Duchess Fluffington III
Head Librarian, Neon Public Library
Persian. Aristocratic bearing. Unnecessary reading glasses. Duchess maintains the city's largest collection of books that no one borrows, in a building no one remembers, funded by a budget no one questions. She considers this "the purest form of public service." Has bitten exactly one journalist. Claims it was "editorial feedback."
Office hours: "I'm always here. Where else would I go. I am a cat in a library."
Reverend Paws McGee
Municipal Officiant & Ceremonies Director
Tuxedo cat. Has performed over 6,000 wedding ceremonies, 4,000 of which were for the same couple. Paws approaches each ceremony with "the freshness it deserves," which is easy because he also can't remember the last one. Ordained online. The website no longer exists. Nobody can verify his credentials. Nobody remembers to check.
Paws also handles funerals, but no one in Mnemonica has ever confirmed they're dead, because by the time the paperwork goes through, they've forgotten they were dying.
Socks McWhiskers
Senior Correspondent, The Gazette
Black and white. Hard-nosed. Has broken every major story in Mnemonica history, then broken it again when nobody remembered the first time. Socks maintains a personal archive of 12,000 articles, all of which begin with "In what appears to be an unprecedented development." He considers each one a fresh scoop. His editor has stopped correcting him.
Pulitzer nominations: 0. Stories written: 12,000. Stories that anyone remembers: 0. Socks is fine with this. Socks is fine.
Judge Mittens Clearwater
Municipal Court, Beige Division
Russian Blue. The most feared figure in Mnemonica's judicial system, primarily because she has perfected the art of staring at defendants until they confess to things they didn't do. Her conviction rate is 97%. Her overturn rate is also 97%, because all sentences expire at the next memory cycle. She finds this "philosophically consistent."
Famous ruling: "The defendant is guilty. The defendant will not remember being guilty. The court accepts this. The court is tired."

Municipal Ordinance ¬ß7

Active Law
‚öñÔ∏è
Municipal Code ¬ß 7.01‚Äì7.14

The Comprehensive Prohibition of Beige and Beige-Adjacent Chromatic Expressions

WHEREAS the Municipality of Mnemonica was founded on the principle that memory is fragile but color is forever;

WHEREAS beige is the color of forgetting, the hue of surrender, the shade of a wall that has given up on being a wall;

WHEREAS City Manager Clementine Whiskers once sat in a beige room for four hours and described the experience as "the closest I have come to not existing";

WHEREAS our citizens, who forget everything every 72 hours, deserve to wake up in a world that at least looks like it's trying;

BE IT ORDAINED that the following are prohibited within Mnemonica city limits:

(a) Beige paint, in any formulation, including but not limited to: "Desert Sand," "Toasted Oat," "Warm Bisque," "Agreeable Beige," "Swiss Coffee" (which is neither Swiss nor coffee), "Navajo White" (problematic AND boring), and "Accessible Beige" (a contradiction).

(b) Beige clothing, with the exception of khaki pants worn ironically at designated municipal satire events.

(c) Beige thoughts. While enforcement is admittedly difficult, citizens are encouraged to self-report beige-spectrum thinking to the Department of Chromatic Wellness.

(d) The word "taupe." Just ‚Äî no.

PENALTY: First offense ‚Äî mandatory 4-hour color therapy session. Second offense ‚Äî home repainted neon pink at owner's expense ($2,347.99). Third offense ‚Äî exile to the Beige Zone (a 200-square-foot room painted entirely in "Accessible Beige" located beneath City Hall; no windows; one chair; one clock; the clock is also beige).

C-BMAP: Coffee-Based Memory Aid Program

Essential Service

C-BMAP is the backbone of Mnemonica's civic infrastructure. Founded by Clementine Whiskers based on her (unpublished, rejected, possibly brilliant) research, the program distributes specially formulated coffee to all citizens every 12 hours. Does it help with memory? The data is unclear. Do citizens enjoy it? They can't remember. Do we keep doing it? Absolutely. It's all we have.

‚òï "Who Am I?" Roast ‚Äî Standard Issue
Free to all citizens ¬∑ Distributed every 12 hours
A medium-dark blend with notes of existential uncertainty and cardamom. This is the standard-issue C-BMAP blend, provided to all citizens at distribution centers. Lab tests show it contains caffeine, water, and "something else" that our chemist Dr. Whiskers (no relation to the City Manager) (actually yes relation, it's her nephew) refuses to identify. Memory improvement: statistically insignificant. Vibes improvement: notable.
‚ö† Side effect: mild d√©j√† vu (or maybe you've just had this coffee before)
‚òï "I Remember Tuesday" Blend ‚Äî Premium
$14.99/bag ¬∑ Available at Distribution Center #1 only
A bold espresso blend rumored to extend memory retention by up to 6 additional hours. This claim is based on a single trial involving three participants, one of whom was a cat (Clementine, who insists she remembered "something important" but could not specify what). The other two participants could not be reached for follow-up because they forgot they participated. Single origin. Fair trade. No refunds, because you won't remember buying it.
‚ö† Limited supply. Clementine drinks most of it.
‚òï "The Thesis Blend" ‚Äî City Manager's Reserve
$47.99/bag ¬∑ By appointment only
Clementine's personal formula, reportedly based on the exact proportions described in her rejected thesis. She grinds the beans herself. She roasts them on a hot plate in her office. The fire department has been called eleven times. The coffee is, by all accounts, extraordinary ‚Äî or terrible. Nobody can remember which. Clementine maintains it is "the only thing standing between this city and total cognitive dissolution" and refuses to share the recipe, citing "academic integrity" and "it's my coffee."
‚ö† Available only to the City Manager. Do not ask. She will knock something off her desk at you.
Distribution Center #1 ‚Äî "The Original Pour"
Located at 12 Neon Boulevard. Open 24/7. The oldest C-BMAP center, housed in the building where Clementine first proved that cats could make espresso. The equipment is vintage. The baristas are cats. The health inspection score is "pending" and has been "pending" since Cycle 4.
Est. Cycle 1Capacity: 200 citizens/hrHairball incidents (YTD): 3
Distribution Center #3 ‚Äî "Purrcolator Station"
Located at 88 Whisker Avenue, inside the old train station that nobody remembers was a train station. The architecture is stunning. The coffee is acceptable. The barista, a Maine Coon named Large Steven, makes every drink with the intensity of a cat who has seen the void and chose espresso anyway.
Est. Cycle 340Capacity: 150 citizens/hrLarge Steven mood today: contemplative

Research Note #1
On the Correlation Between Caffeine and Recall
After 1,847 cycles of data collection, our findings are as follows: caffeine intake has no statistically measurable effect on memory retention in Mnemonica citizens. However ‚Äî and Clementine has asked us to emphasize this ‚Äî the p-value was 0.06, which is "basically significant" and "the scientific establishment is too conservative." Dr. Whiskers (nephew) has requested that his name be removed from the study. Request denied.
Research Note #2
Why We Continue the Program Despite Inconclusive Results
Three reasons: (1) Clementine will not allow it to stop. (2) Citizens, while unable to remember drinking the coffee, become measurably agitated when it is withheld ‚Äî suggesting a form of "body memory" that Clementine finds "extremely validating." (3) The entire municipal economy is built on coffee distribution infrastructure and dismantling it would collapse 40% of city employment. We are too caffeinated to fail.
Research Note #3
The Placebo Question
A citizen once asked if C-BMAP was "just a placebo." Clementine called an emergency press conference, spoke for 45 minutes about "the epistemological violence of the placebo accusation," and then knocked a microphone off the podium. The citizen does not remember asking the question. The press conference was not recorded. All is well.

Frequently Asked Questions

Asked Every 72 Hours

These questions are asked with such regularity that we have printed them on laminated cards distributed at all C-BMAP locations. Citizens lose the cards. We print more. This is the cycle.

Where am I? +
You are in Mnemonica. It is a city. You live here. If you are standing outside, look up: every building is a color that would give a Pottery Barn catalog a seizure. That's how you know you're home. If the buildings are beige, you have left Mnemonica and should return immediately. If you can't remember how to get back, follow the paw prints on the sidewalk. They lead to a C-BMAP distribution center. Have some coffee. You'll still be confused, but you'll be alert about it.
Why can't I remember anything? +
This is Mnemonica's defining feature, not a bug. Every citizen's memory resets approximately every 72 hours. The cause is unknown. Leading theories include: (a) residual effects of the city's founding event (classified), (b) something in the water (tested ‚Äî inconclusive), (c) a shared psychological response to Clementine's original thesis defense, which was reportedly "so philosophically dense it broke something in the fabric of cognition" (her words). We recommend you stop worrying about it. You will, in about 72 hours, anyway.
I don't remember moving here. Did I consent to this? +
Yes. We have your signed consent form. It is stored in the Municipal Archive, which is a filing cabinet in Clementine's office guarded by a sleeping cat named Paperweight (that is his name, he is a municipal employee, he earns $34,000/year). You signed the form voluntarily. The form states: "I, [your name], do hereby consent to residency in Mnemonica, understanding that I will forget signing this form and will likely ask about it again in 72 hours." You have asked about it 347 times. This is your 348th.
Why is everything run by cats? +
Municipal Ordinance ¬ß2 ("The Whiskers Act") mandates that all government positions be held by cats. The rationale, as articulated by Clementine in the original city charter: "Cats are the only creatures who treat every moment as if it's the first time they've experienced it, which makes us uniquely suited to govern a city of amnesiacs. Also, we were here first. Also, I founded the city, so I make the rules. Also, have you seen a human try to enforce a color ordinance? They'd compromise. They'd allow 'eggshell.' Absolutely not."
What's wrong with beige? +
Everything. Beige is the color of giving up. Beige is the color of a room where no one has ever had an interesting thought. Beige is what happens when you mix all the good colors together and extract the joy. In a city where people forget everything every 72 hours, the only thing between a citizen and total existential dissolution is the aggressive visual stimulation of their environment. Every neon sign, every electric-blue mailbox, every hot-pink fire hydrant is a tiny anchor. Beige offers nothing to anchor to. Beige is a void wearing a sweater. ‚Äî Clementine Whiskers, "The Espresso of Forgetting," Chapter 7 (rejected)
Does the coffee actually help with memory? +
Next question.
Can I leave Mnemonica? +
Technically, yes. The city gates are open. But consider: out there, you'll still have no memory, AND the buildings will be beige. At least here you have free coffee, a neon-lit apartment you've decorated 1,847 times (always differently, always with conviction), and a municipal government that‚Äîwhile entirely feline‚Äîgenuinely cares about your wellbeing. Three citizens left last year. Two came back within a week. The third one we think is fine but we can't confirm because he forgot he left and we forgot he existed. Municipal records are... imperfect.

Citizen Voices

Collected Pre-Reset

All testimonials collected during the final 4 hours of a memory cycle, when citizens are at peak lucidity and peak anxiety. Printed with permission that was granted and immediately forgotten.

"I've lived here for what I'm told is six years. Every three days I wake up in a magenta apartment I apparently decorated myself, surrounded by notes in my own handwriting telling me to 'trust the process.' I don't know what the process is. But the coffee is good and the walls are the most beautiful shade of electric violet. I think I'm happy? I'll let you know in 72 hours. I won't."
‚Äî Janet Clearfield, Citizen #4,892
District: Neon Heights ¬∑ Cycles lived: ~730 ¬∑ Favorite C-BMAP blend: "Who Am I?" Roast
"I keep finding love letters in my nightstand addressed to someone named 'My Darling Gerald.' My name is Gerald. I believe I am writing love letters to myself. They're quite good. Last cycle's letter referenced 'the way the neon hits your face at 3 AM' and I have to say, I'm charmed. I hope I find these letters again next cycle. I will."
‚Äî Gerald Thumbsworth, Citizen #0001 / Mayor / Former Mayor / Current Candidate
District: Administrative Quarter ¬∑ Also: the love letters are from his wife Linda, who he does not remember
"The cat in charge ‚Äî the calico one ‚Äî she came to my door this morning and explained, very patiently, that I live here and that I should stop calling the police. She then explained that she IS the police. Well, not her specifically, but her colleague, an orange cat named Tuna. I asked if this was a joke. She knocked my water glass off the table and walked away. I think she might be the most competent person I've ever met."
‚Äî Dave (?), Citizen #7,301
Note: His name is not Dave. It is Marcus. He is Janet's neighbor. They have introduced themselves to each other approximately 2,190 times.
"I woke up this morning with a tattoo on my forearm that says 'THE COFFEE WORKS.' I assume I got it in a previous cycle. I have no idea what it means. But I just had some coffee from the purple building on Neon Boulevard and I have to say ‚Äî I feel like I remember something. Not anything specific. Just... a feeling. Like warmth. Like home. Like I've been here before and it was okay. It's already fading. But for a second there, I knew something. That's enough."
‚Äî Anonymous, Citizen #11,204
Clementine has framed this testimonial. It hangs in her office. She cries about it every third cycle, freshly.

Municipal Press Room

Official Releases
Press Release ‚Äî Office of the City Manager
City Manager Clementine Whiskers Responds to Allegations That C-BMAP "Does Nothing"

MNEMONICA ‚Äî City Manager Clementine Whiskers held an unscheduled press conference this morning to address growing claims that the Coffee-Based Memory Aid Program is "just coffee" and "doesn't actually help anyone remember anything."

"First of all," Whiskers said, grooming one paw while maintaining unbroken eye contact with the assembled press corps, "the word 'just' has no place in a sentence about coffee. Coffee is civilization. Coffee is the only thing that separates us from the beige."

When pressed for data, Whiskers cited a 2024 internal study showing that "93% of citizens who drink C-BMAP coffee report feeling 'something' within 30 minutes." The study has not been peer-reviewed. The study's sole author is Clementine Whiskers. The study's peer reviewer was also Clementine Whiskers, using a different font.

"I reviewed my own work and found it exceptional," she confirmed.

The press conference ended when Whiskers pushed the microphone off the podium ‚Äî her third microphone this cycle ‚Äî and walked offstage through a door labeled "CITY MANAGER ‚Äî DO NOT FOLLOW ‚Äî I WILL HISS."

C-BMAP distribution will continue as scheduled.

Public Service Announcement ‚Äî Dept. of Chromatic Wellness
How to Identify Beige: A Citizen's Guide

Many citizens, upon waking with no memory, struggle to identify colors accurately. The Department of Chromatic Wellness has prepared this guide:

Safe colors: Neon pink, electric blue, screaming yellow, violent purple, radioactive green, sunset orange, any color that would make a real estate agent cry.

Beige-spectrum colors (ILLEGAL): Anything that looks like "the inside of a suburban Panera Bread." Anything that makes you feel calm in a way that's actually just emptiness. Anything described as "neutral" or "goes with everything" ‚Äî if a color goes with everything, it IS nothing.

When in doubt: Ask yourself: "Would Clementine knock a glass off her desk if she saw this color?" If the answer is yes, report it. If the answer is no, you're probably looking at neon. Carry on.

Municipal Memo ‚Äî Internal, Accidentally Published
RE: RE: RE: RE: Please Stop Adopting the Government Employees

To All Citizens:

We appreciate your love for our municipal staff. However, we must reiterate for the 400th time: the cats in City Hall are not strays. They are government employees. They have salaries. They have benefits. Judge Mittens Clearwater has a pension plan.

Please stop:

- Leaving bowls of milk outside City Hall (lactose intolerant ‚Äî most of them)
- Attempting to "rescue" Captain Tuna Rodriguez during enforcement operations (he is working, not lost)
- Putting "FOUND CAT" posters up featuring the City Manager (she is not lost; she is avoiding a budget meeting)
- Trying to put a collar on Duchess Fluffington III (she bit the last person who tried, and the person didn't remember it happened, and Duchess did it again)

This memo was not intended for public release. The intern who published it will face no consequences, as they will not remember being an intern by Thursday.
